Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Determining Disk Galaxy Evolutionary State through Spatially-Resolved Gas Mass Fractions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Current research in galaxy formation and evolution seeks to answer one main question: how did the heterogeneous universe we observe--with its vast tracts of virtually-empty space between immensely compact islands of stars and hot gas--form from an overwhelmingly homogeneous beginning, the Big Bang? This is indicated robustly in individual galaxies by the gas mass fraction, the percentage of mass contained in both hot plasma and cool atomic & molecular hydrogen--as opposed to mass contained in stars. A small gas fraction indicates--in general--an evolved system with reduced capacity for forming new stars, while a large gas fraction suggests the potential for large star formation and metal-enrichment of the interstellar medium. In collaboration with Prof. Yanmei Chen (Nanjing University: Nanjing, Jiansu, China), the PI will construct statistically-robust estimates of stellar mass, and compare to his existing measurements of spatially-resolved gas mass. The radial variation of gas mass fraction will be compared with estimates of total galaxy mass, star formation rate, and galaxy environment density.

In the new era of integral-field spectroscopic surveys (such as MaNGA, SAMI, and CALIFA), responsive, robust, and cheap methods of stellar-continuum fitting are necessary counterparts to large, nightly datastreams. Most methods of stellar-mass estimation are computationally costly, and do not take advantage of modern advances in statistics and machine learning. Prof. Yanmei Chen has developed a method of fitting the stellar continuum, which relies on the one-off principal-component analysis (PCA) of a library of single stellar population (SSP) models, which yields order-of-magnitude improvements in compute time and will enable the use of larger, more flexible SSP libraries. The PI has obtained a set of fully-theoretical SSP models, with a spectral resolution exceeding that of MaNGA. Such SSPs include near-IR features like the CaII triplet (necessary for breaking the age-metallicity degeneracy), and improve on existing models of the thermally-pulsating asymptotic giant branch (TP-AGB). Combining the high-resolution stellar library with Chen's PCA code (translated by the PI from IDL to Python) will yield measurable improvements in resolved stellar-mass estimates. When paired with resolved total gas mass (HI + H2), estimated using new optical-spectroscopic methods (rather than from expensive, radio-band follow-up), a census of stars and gas in nearby galaxies will result. These single-source estimates of galaxy evolutionary state will improve current knowledge of galactic chemical evolution and mass assembly, and place the Milky Way in a cosmic context.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of China.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gas fraction (the portion of a galaxy's mass contributed by gaseous atomic & neuatral hydrogen, as well as small amounts of heavier elements) is one of the most reliable indicators of a galaxy's history. Since each epoch of star-formation in a galaxy transforms clouds of cold gas into stars, the amount of gas present relative to stars will indicate where the galaxy lies in its life-cycle. Other measurements, such as abundance of heavy elements within the gas (heavy elements are created inside stars and dispersed into the environment when the stars die), are related to the gas fraction according to whether (and how much) a galaxy as replenished its supply of gas over time.

Some attempts have been made to measure gas fraction in large samples of galaxies other than our Milky Way, but there are precious few cases where gas fraction has been measured in a resolved sense (that is, it is rare to be able to measure different gas fractions in different regions of a single galaxy). These resolved measurements are important because a galaxy is not a single point; rather, different regions of galaxies experience different effects from their environment, by way of rotation, interaction with other galaxies and influence of active galactic nuclei, supermassive black holes thought to reside at the cetners of most galaxies.

To measure gas fraction requires two separate techniques---each with their own challenges. Measuring the mass of the stars requires either careful dynamical studies (precise measurements of how the stars are moving in bulk) or comparing the light given off by those stars to theories of how stars form and evolve. The latter class of measurement was the subject of the bulk of the work for this award. To measure the gas mass, it is usually necessary to rely on single-pointing estimates from radio or submillimeter telescopes, but there are promising alternatives (originally contained in this proposal was one such alternative, but a concern for carefully validating our results for stellar-mass measurements precluded us from pursuing it).

We obtain estimates of resolved galaxy stellar mass for galaxies in the SDSS-IV/MaNGA spectroscopic galaxy survey using principal component analysis (PCA). PCA is a statistical technique which finds simple ways to explain complex data. For example, each galaxy spectrum contains approximately 4000 separate measurements of light intensity, each at a specific wavelength (color). However, these spectral channels are extremely covariate (that is, they don't all convey unique information). By leveraging knowledge about the star-formation patterns which typically arise in galaxies, we have simplified the problem of explaining the colors of light arising from star-forming galaxies by a factor of hundreds.

In so doing, we have enabled reliable measurements of a wide variety of properties of galaxy regions: for instance, we can reliably estimate mass-to-light ratio, which describes how heavy a population of stars are, relative to the light they give off. This gives rise to simple measurements of that population's mass, simply by multiplying by the amount of light received. Other measurements, such as the properties of the dust in the galaxy or the heavy-element content of the stars, can also be estimated, though with less certainty.

Since award start, we (Pace, with co-investigators Tremonti, Chen, Bershady, and others) have written and released a small software library which performs the dimensionality-reduction operations and estimates properties of populations of stars. We have submitted an extensive paper outlining our findings in more detail to the Astrophysical Journal: in brief, we provide extensive validation of our estimates of stellar mass-to-light ratio; compare our resolved stellar-mass estimates to those from dynamical studies; add the mass estimates from across the spatial extents of galaxies to yield estimates of total galaxy stellar mass; find that resolved spectroscopy yields slightly higher total masses than does adding together all light from a galaxy; and compare the total masses from our method with previous estimates from photometric (four-filter) imaging.
